unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Math Program: Test Statistic and $p$-value
question_text:
Suppose a high school principal wishes to determine if students in her after-school math program perform better than those not in the program.
The principal randomly selected $115\text{ students}$ for an after-school study session that runs $3\text{ days per week}$ for $1\text{ hour}$ each day, focusing solely on math.
The grade distribution of these students’ math grades is compared to the historical grade distribution of students’ math grades at this high school. The data is below:
When performing a chi-squared goodness of fit test, the appropriate chi-squared test statistic and $p$-value are approximately what?

solution:
The chi-squared test statistic is the summation of each difference of the observed minus expected counts squared, divided by the expected counts as given by the formula below:

$$\sum{\dfrac{(O-E)^2 }{E}}$$

Substitute the values to get the test statistic as shown:

$$=\dfrac{(28-20.7)^2}{20.7}+\dfrac{(38-36.8)^2}{36.8}+\dfrac{(36-28.75)^2}{28.75}+\dfrac{(9-23)^2}{23}+\dfrac{(4-5.75)^2}{5.75} $$

$$= 13.496$$

Use the chi-squared distribution table to look up $13.51$ with $n-1 = 5-1 = 4$ to find the test statistic is between the critical values $13.28$ and $14.86$, and the upper tail probabilities are between $0.005$ and $0.01$.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'A'.
